thread.title: Rangers offseason issue No. 2: Improving team balance could cost this key contributor
thread.title_full: Rangers offseason issue No. 2: Improving team balance could cost this key contributor | Dallas Morning News

author: Evan Grant
title: Rangers offseason issue No. 2: Improving team balance could cost this key contributor
text:
The Rangers may have had a hard time sleeping after their season came to an abrupt end Wednesday afternoon, but regardless, it's time to put 2015 to bed.
And it's time to start focusing on 2016, because, well, the business of baseball never ends.
With that in mind, here is the No. 2 of five major issues the Rangers will spend a significant amount of time trying to solve this winter:
Because the regular lineup was so left-handed heavy, the Rangers faced more left-handed starters (66) than any other team in the majors in 2015. The late-season addition of Mike Napoli helped the club finish 35-31 after a slow start.
"We're very left-handed," Daniels said. "So that's something that we'll talk about. I don't think it's a coincidence we faced the most left-handed starters of any team in the big leagues this year. Teams adjusted accordingly."
Bringing back Napoli, a free agent, might be the easiest, most cost-effective way of better balancing the middle of the lineup.
It also might cost the Rangers Mitch Moreland.
Moreland, who made $2.95 million in 2015, is heading into his last season of arbitration and is likely to see his salary nearly double after a career-best year. There will be plenty of demand for a guy capable of hitting 25 to 30 homers who will make $6 million or less in 2016, particularly from National League teams, which face lefties much less frequently.
If the Rangers traded Moreland, it would open up some extra cash to dedicate toward Napoli, who would slide in as a right-handed-hitting first baseman. Daniels acknowledged Friday that there has been "very casual" conversation with Napoli in which both the club and player expressed a desire to extend the reunion.
"We were much better against [left-handers] the last two months," Daniels said. "Internally, guys made improvements, and [Napoli] being in there helped a lot."
If clubs engage the Rangers on Moreland, it could also create a more legitimate spot for Joey Gallo on the big league roster if he's ready. He could play first base against some right-handers, spell Adrian Beltre a bit at third, perhaps spell Prince Fielder occasionally at DH and even play some left for Josh Hamilton.
